This concludes the basics for beginning an Assault mission.Next, we will cover the main points to consider during the mission itself.1�
When an Assault mission begins, you will be transported to an area where the level of enemies is based on the highest-level member of your party.1�
It is also possible to accept a voluntary level restriction during Assault. In this case, your party will be sent to an area based upon the adjusted level limit.1�
Once you have arrived in the area, the time limit for the mission will be announced. If you do not complete the mission objectives within this time, the mission will be considered a failure.1�
To successfully complete a mission, it is necessary to activate the ��rune of release�� that appears after the mission objectives have been fulfilled.1�
It is possible to abandon a mission and be transported out of the Assault area by using homing fireflies to guide you. Naturally, the mission will be considered a failure in this case.1�
Before being transported to the Assault area, all party members will be issued with homing fireflies.1�
Homing fireflies are temporary items that cannot be taken out of an Assault area.1�
Other temporary items will also be available during Assault missions.1�
This concludes the Assault mission explanation.Lastly, I will give you an overview of the rewards available upon successfully completing an Assault mission.1�
After successfully completing an Assault mission, the Empire will award you with Assault Points.1�
These points are only awarded for participation in Assault missions, and are accumulated separately for each Assault area.1�
Each area has specific items available that can be purchased in exchange for Assault Points.1�
You can check your Assault Point totals and purchase items from the counters to your left.1�

��Sanction�� is a magic spell that we use to observe and assess mercenaries' actions.1�
Defeating enemies while you have Sanction cast on you will raise your Imperial Standing. Also, the stronger the monsters you fight, the higher your Imperial Standing will become.1�
When fighting in a beastman stronghold that has taken the Astral Candescence, your Imperial Standing will rise by a significant amount as thanks for your participation in the recovery effort.1�
Sanction is also necessary in order to receive crystals from the enemies you defeat.1�
But you must take caution. Stepping too far out of the Empire's boundaries will cause Sanction to wear off.1�
You can raise your Imperial Standing by defeating enemies while you have Sanction cast on you.1�
Saving a captured prisoner in a beastman stronghold and submitting archaic mirrors to Imperial guards will also result in an increased Imperial Standing.1�
You can view your Imperial Standing by selecting ��Besieged�� under ��Region Info.��1�
You can also speak to me at any time to exchange your Imperial Standing credits for items.1�
��Besieged�� occurs when the beastman armies breach the walls of Al Zahbi.1�
Everyone in town who is capable of wielding a weapon is called to action to defend Al Zahbi alongside the Imperial Army.1�
The beastmen's main purpose is to enter the Hall of Binding and wrest the ��Astral Candescence�� from the Empire's control.1�
You need not know what the Astral Candescence is.1�
All you must know is that it is your duty to protect the five Serpent Generals who hold the keys to the Hall of Binding, and to drive the beastman hordes from the Imperial capital.1�
The Empire's safety and its future rest on your capable shoulders!Rest assured that you will be rewarded for your efforts.1�
The Empire's defense is entrusted to five generals.1�
Each possesses a name corresponding to the symbols of the Empire--the serpents of flame, water, stone, gales, and sky.1�
Furthermore, the mirrors used to open the Hall of Binding are divided among their possession. Thus, the generals' fates determine the tide of battle.1�
If all five generals should fall in battle, the Hall of Binding will open, and the beastmen will be able to seize the Astral Candescence.1�
It is your responsibility to prevent such a disaster from happening. We are depending on you!1�
When the Astral Candescence is safely resting on its plinth in the Hall of Binding, it emanates waves that bestow special bonuses to Sanction.1�
The first bonus is a slight boost to the amount of experience points received from battles. You will receive this effect simply by having Sanction cast on you.1�
There are several other bonus effects, but you must sacrifice some of your Imperial Standing credits in order to receive them.1�
Keep in mind that the bonuses become more powerful with the number of times the Imperial capital is successfully defended.1�

The basic rules of Brenner are as follows:1�
First, the participants divide into two teams. Each side's camp contains the same number of ��Flammen-Brenner.��1�
At the beginning of the match, half of each side's Flammen-Brenner will be ablaze with ��Flamme,�� or flame, while the other half will remain unlit.1�
Participants can seize a Flamme from the opposing side's Flammen-Brenner and carry it around the Isle.1�
The goal is to steal your opponent's Flamme and use them to light your side's Flammen-Brenner.1�
The side that succeeds in lighting all of its Flammen-Brenner will be declared the winner after a specified amount of time.1�
If neither side is victorious before the match ends, the outcome will be judged based on the score. The ��match score�� section of the rulebook contains more information on this subject.1�
Brenner is significantly divided into public and private matches. Official matches are held periodically according to level and feature general participation.1�
You cannot reserve the Isle when an official match is being held.1�
No items are necessary for participation, but a minor fee will be collected. You will be unable to participate if your level is too low.1�

The match outcome will be recorded unless the number of participants fails to exceed 
� members, or if there are fewer than 
 members in a match where the two sides' numbers differ. In such cases, the game will be considered a training match and will not be recorded.1�
Private matches require a reservation, and participation may be limited. The Master of Ceremonies (MC) can freely adjust the rules and control match proceedings.1�
��LS Liga�� is a form of private match. You can learn more about LS Liga by speaking to a Marshal.1�
A Flammen-Brenner is a device that contains a Flamme (flame). The Flammen-Brenner is covered by a grate that will open after taking a set amount of damage, exposing the Flamme.1�
The participants must utilize this chance to seize the Flamme before the grate recloses. Once the grate is closed, the Flammen-Brenner will begin recovering from the damage it has been dealt.1�
If you manage to open the opposing team's Flammen-Brenner and capture their Flamme, you should make haste to light one of the Flammen-Brenner on your side.1�
After a certain amount of time, the Flamme will burn out and the opposing team's Flammen-Brenner will be relit.1�
Also, please note that you cannot quicken your pace using any special abilities while you are in possession of a Flamme.1�
In the event that neither side fulfills the conditions for victory, the outcome of the match will be evaluated based on score.1�

Ten points are awarded to each side for every lit Flammen-Brenner, while one point is awarded whenever a Flamme is captured, used to light a Flammen-Brenner, or recaptured from an opponent. One point is also awarded for protecting the Flammen-Brenner for a certain period of time.1�
Like Ballista, quarry (/quarry) can be used while playing Brenner. Participants may use this ability to dig up Petras and temporary items.1�
However, unlike Ballista Petras, Brenner Petras have no effect on the match score. You can trade a Petra to a Pursuivant to recover your HP and MP at no expense to TP.1�
Sprint cannot be used while carrying a Petra. Also, please note that the scout ability cannot be used in Brenner.1�
Petras will be lost in the event of a KO, but can be carried over from one match to another.1�
The sprint (/sprint) ability can be used to increase the player's speed when not in possession of a Flamme or Petras.1�
In the event of a KO, you will be returned to your team's camp. However, recovery will take longer the more often you fall in battle.1�
In other words, you will receive a penalty if you fall immediately after recovering from KO. In addition, your TP will be reduced to zero and you will lose any Petras in your possession.1�
I'm sorry. I wasn't listening. Could you start over from the beginning?1�

What do you wish to know about?Basic rules.About the Petra.About Sprint.About Scout.About Gate Breach.About area-specific rules.About returning to battle.About special rules.Nothing at the moment.1�

Ballista is an exercise once used by the San d'Orian armies to train the Royal Knights in the art of the siege. The word ��ballista�� means ��to throw a stone,�� and the game has been a part of Vana'dielian military history for centuries.1�
The rules are simple.Ballista is played by two teams over a number of hours (Vana'diel time). The team with the most points at the end of the match is the victor.1�

Players from both teams must search for Petras that a Herald has buried in various locations across the battlefield. The players must then take these stones and throw them into targets known as Rooks.1�
These Rooks can appear in various locations around the battlefield, and both teams are allowed to throw their Petras into them.1�
Finally, a player's strength is adjusted depending on his or her level. It is felt that this ultimately allows for a more balanced battle.1�
Petras can be buried anywhere. Once a player believes he or she has found one, the Quarry (/quarry) command should be used to dig up the area at his or her feet.1�
Sometimes a player may find items other than Petras, such as potions. These temporary items can only be used during the current match (or Best of Three series).1�

Players can carry more than one Petra, but they cannot throw the stones away once they have obtained them.However, players will lose their Petras if they:(1) Successfully throw them into a rook.(2) Leave the area.(3) Are knocked out.1�
But don't forget, a player will be unable to use the Sprint command while in possession of a Petra. And, players can only use the Scout command if they carry one of the stones.1�
As one can see, careful planning and impeccable timing are the keys to victory.1�
All participants of Ballista will have the ability to use the Sprint command. This will temporarily increase one's movement speed, creating a better chance to find and obtain Petras.1�
However, remember that once a player has obtained a Petra, he or she will be unable to use the Sprint command. In its place, though, one may use the Scout command.1�
The locations of the Rooks are constantly changing. This makes it quite difficult to find the targets by just randomly walking about the area.1�

Communication with one's team members is, of course, one way to locate Rooks. However, another way is by using the Scout command. This will inform a player of the approximate location of the nearest Rook.1�
Finally, Scout can only be used when a player is carrying a Petra. Because Sprint cannot be used at this time, players must be weary of approaching enemies.1�
So, a Petra has been obtained and a Rook located. Now all that's left is tossing the stone in, right? Wrong.1�
There is one aspect of Ballista that has yet to be mentioned...and this is where the real battle begins.1�
To throw a Petra into a Rook, a player must first wait until the Rook's gate is open. This takes impeccable timing, as the gate is only open for a short while.1�
But not just anyone can score points this way. A player must first take down a member of the opposing team and achieve Gate Breach status.Only then will his or her shots count.1�
This extreme method of combat is what made the ancient game of Ballista famous, and transformed its participants into heroes.1�
Running about looking for stones is no different from a child's game of hide-and-seek. Knowing when to strike is what separates the men from the boys.1�

After being KO'd, if a player chooses to be revived at the spot he was defeated, 100% of all HP and 50% of all MP will be restored. In addition, the player will maintain 50% of the TP he had earned.1�
If a player chooses to return to their force's camp, HP and MP will be fully restored, but all TP will be lost.1�
